storyInfo: Vina bids farewell to the crown stealer who loves Victoria and tells her a tale steeped in ambiguity—how, after the war is won, she declines the coronation offered by the supposedly deceased King Alistair II.

attributes.content: <p=1>Defense Forces Temporary Detention Room</><p=2>December 25th, 1098, 8:32 P.M.</>
attributes.name: group_location_stamp

attributes.content: Phew—Zone 2 is finally all cleaned up, now it's just Zone 4 left. How are you doing? Tough work, eh? Want to take a break?
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: I'm cleaning just as fast as you are, as you can plainly see.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: You don't need to try and accommodate me just because I'm an Infected.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: That's not it at all. I just thought you must be tired, with everything you've been through and all.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: Oh, I thought... never mind. As for that incident with the crown, I'm fully clear on that now.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: It was just a spur-of-the-moment thing! Besides, you're not the only one who wanted to do that.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: Actually, it seems like all of a sudden, people aren't as afraid of the Infected anymore.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: That's because we're in Londinium. The policies instituted by the Speaker and Parliament have, at the very least, stopped many people from openly showing fear and resentment towards the Infected.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: But according to a Columbian friend of mine, outside of Londinium, things haven't changed.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Anyway, thanks for helping with the cleanup; we would've had the captain on us again without you.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: I should be the one thanking you for not shackling me. Having something to do helps put my mind at ease.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: If you ask me, you need not worry about Parliament's decision. Think about it. Of all the places in Londinium where they could have detained you, why did they choose the Defense Forces' lockup?
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: It's because we're all either old war buddies or familiar faces who can look out for you. Don't worry. Once things cool down, we'll find a reason for you to go home.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: The protestors outside the Speaker's office, they're the ones who are missing the picture. We all know what kind of person Vina is.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: Hmm? Are you feeling alright? Do you need something to drink?
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: You're saying... the Speaker is going to release me?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: I'm saying just rest here for now, where it's safe, until things die down out there.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: The captain didn't allow you to have a radio or read the newspaper, right? It's because he was worried that you might get to thinking too much.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: If you're still feeling jittery, my good buddy—he gets thrown in the drunk tank every few days—he's stashed some premium hooch around here somewhere.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: I'll go grab a few bottles for you.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: Diane gives a faint, wry smile as she strains to catch the sounds coming from outside.
But aside from the faint sound of water running through pipes, she hears nothing but the distant drills of the Defense Forces.
Ever since she was brought in here, she has been more or less cut off from the outside world.
I wonder if Eliseo is doing alright?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: I really should have let him know beforehand. He must be so worried about me now…
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Indeed. He went to nearly everyone he knows to plead on your behalf.
Madam Speaker!
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Good. They aren't treating you like some common criminal.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: And you made sure of that?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: No. They did it on their own—they believe you don't deserve this sentence.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Many came to me on your behalf. Your friends, my friends… our comrades-in-arms, and even some civilians who don't know you at all.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: —Diane, I snatched some of my buddy's liquor for you.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: He takes a big swig of whiskey.
Urk!
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: Before the soldier even reaches Diane and Vina, he snaps to attention, the whiskey caught awkwardly in his mouth—too afraid to swallow or spit it out.
He quickly hides the bottle behind him and salutes Vina.
Gulp!
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: No need to hide it, Patel.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: As I recall, Horn did mention that drinking is prohibited in the barracks.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: (Swallows) Uhh... ahem…
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: Yes, Vina! But… this is… uh…
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: I won't tell Horn, but in return, you'll keep my visiting Diane a secret.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: And set the bottle down, will you? Weren't you bringing it to Diane, anyway?
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Uh… alright. Vina, you came here to discuss the plans with Diane, right?
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: Yes.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: See, Diane? I told you not to worry, didn't I?
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: I'll go finish cleaning Zone 4. I've been on duty all day, and I didn't see anyone here.
attributes.name: Diligent Guard

attributes.content: Would you like a taste of the whiskey Patel left? It doesn't smell all that bad.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Diane shakes her head slightly, a bit downcast.
Mind if I have a sip, then? Meeting with those dukes has left me parched.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Madam Speaker, did you put me here because you really wanted to…?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: We thought you'd feel better among old friends. You would rather I threw you in solitary?
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: No, of course not.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Honestly, I'm not as resolute as you think. My past isn't much different from yours, or from that of most Londiniers.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Diane, I did hesitate over my decision.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: So, does your visit mean Parliament has come to a verdict?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: (Sigh) I feel it best that I inform you of Parliament's decision in person.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: I bid you adieu, Lieutenant Diane Weber of the former 6th Column, 10th Infantry Regiment. You are unquestionably a war hero.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Thank you for your great service to our homeland.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Parliament...? I see. Madam Speaker, when will it happen?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Tomorrow.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Alright.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Have you any regrets?
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Have you?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Perhaps my biggest regret is that, after the war, I didn't immediately strip off this outfit and hide myself away back in Norport.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Ha, you would never have done that. I know you. The Siege will never abandon our homeland, and the Speaker of Londinium will never abandon Victoria.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: ...Hah.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: I have no regrets either, Vina—may I call you that?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: You may.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: We've met many times and fought side by side just as often. But today, I think, is the first day we can truly call ourselves friends.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Vina, before I go, would you share a drink with me?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: When you walked alone into the Palace of Westhaleg, everyone believed that the woman who emerged would be wearing the crown.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: 'A hero must one day be crowned king.'
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Every collection of fairytales in that old bookstore on Baker Street had a story like that. It was my favorite place to go before I enlisted.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: I really did want to witness history, Vina.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: But I let you down. I let a lot of people down.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Yes... You could have been a great ruler.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Just because I wanted to make Londinium a better place? Didn't the old king, the one who was hanged public, also want to make Londinium, to make all of Victoria, a better place?
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Things rarely go as planned.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Sometimes, what you believe is right may look wrong to others. I've only recently begun to understand that.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Then what is there to do?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: I'm still searching for that answer, Diane.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Someone I trust told me to try to accept those who hate me and to stand firm in my own sense of justice…
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: I'm still learning… but I never imagined this path would be so lonely.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: You're drunk… Vina.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Vina shakes her head. She draws her sword and hands it to Diane.
Do you remember Kyngasycath, the Sighs of Kings?
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Yes. I took it from your own hands, after all.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: After the battle, I discovered that it had completely dulled. The smiths worked tirelessly, day and night, to reforge it for me.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: This new sword is heavier. It carries the weight of even greater expectations than before.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Diane, this sword reminds me every day of the right path—
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: The future of Victoria doesn't rest with me or Parliament. It rests on all of you—those who reclaimed our home with their own strength.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Vina, I have one last question.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: What really happened in the Palace of Westhaleg that day?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: What kind of story would you like to hear?
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: A heroic fairytale that'll make it into the books of that old bookstore, or the truth, so plain that it's almost boring?
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Haha.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Diane takes a long swig of her drink, her hand brushing over the cold steel of the sword.
To be honest, I prefer the old sword… When I used it to strike down our enemies, those were the moments I felt closest to Victoria.
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Back when I was living a simple, uneventful life, I never imagined I'd have thoughts like these…
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: And besides, there's hardly any time left to savor those quiet, pre-war days, is there?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Vina, forgive me, but I can't save the last bit of this whiskey for you. I really need it—
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: (Choking up) Why now, of all times, am I suddenly afraid to die?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: (Choking back tears) Vina, before I'm completely drunk, would you tell me one last fairytale?
attributes.name: Diane

attributes.content: Her tears fall on the sword, sliding down its blade. 'Drip', 'drip'...
Diane… you already know the stories of the past, and you were there for the best parts of this fairytale.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: But you may not know how it ends.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: That day, I entered the Palace of Westhaleg, tore down the Sarkaz banner, and was about to leave—when suddenly, I heard someone call my name from the throne room.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: 'Alexandrina Vina Victoria.'
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Then I pushed open the door that had been sealed for so long.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: I saw—
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: my father. Alistair II, speaking to me.
My Alexandrina! You're finally home.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: Come sit by my side, daughter of Victoria.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: Vina couldn't make out the King's face.
The golden mask blended with his golden hair, radiating authority and an air of mystery.
He was Victoria personified.
My daughter, are you afraid of me? Are you afraid of Victoria?
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: Vina, never reveal even the slightest hint of fear to your subjects. Your teacher should have taught you that.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: You died long ago.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Twenty-six years ago, they hanged you from the gallows.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Laughable! Who could kill Victoria?!
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: Those greedy condorwings thought they could tear the flesh from my body to feed themselves.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: They were so blinded by fear that they conspired in regicide, all so they could feast upon the lands of the Aslans for their own gain.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: But no one can kill us—not the dukes, not the Red Dragon. We are the beating heart of Victoria!
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: So that's why… your statue in the Mausoleum of Kings was never completed…
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: The dukes never truly laid you to rest; you've been here all along.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: What little courage they possessed drove them to confine me in this throne room, but never to claim my throne. Cowardly usurpers!
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: They fear my people; they fear my Steam Knights; they fear us, Vina.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: My daughter, tell me, do my people still remember me? Do my knights still guard our palace?
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: The people of Victoria have long since adapted to life without a monarch. As for your knights, they're all gone.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: They were murdered by the very people they were sworn to protect.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: And what of you, Vina?
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: I… I can barely remember what you look like.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Then come closer. Take off my mask and look closely… you'll see only yourself, Alexandrina. The blood of the royal line flows in us both.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: I'm sorry, my child, that I failed to keep my promise.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: I intended to hand you a peaceful and powerful Victoria, yet betrayal has left me sitting here, rotting on my throne, for over twenty years.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: But at last, you've returned. Take my scepter, wear my crown…
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: Proclaim to our people that their sovereign has returned.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: Purge our land of all dissent and punish every coward who betrayed the crown. Let glory endure—this is Victoria's rightful way!
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: The king's scepter struck heavily against the throne platform, its dull echo reverberating.
…Blood was never the source of our strength.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: How familiar those words are—just like my defiant boasts to my own father.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: (Chuckles) You still have much to learn, my daughter. Let me teach you a long-overdue lesson: the meaning of 'royal power'!
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: Still, I grant you the right to oppose me.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: Alexandrina, return to my side, and listen.
attributes.name: Alistair II

attributes.content: No. You're already dead, Your Majesty. All that remains here is your echo, lost in the glories of a bygone empire.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: I do not need you to grant me anything, nor do I need you to validate the strength of my convictions.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: ...I just want you to rest in peace, Father.
attributes.name: Vina

attributes.content: Vina tightened her grip on her hammer, stepped onto the platform, and walked toward the Empire's last glimmer of twilight.
